title: Rain: Heavy Rain Causes Havoc in Bengaluru, Uproots 70 Trees | Bengaluru News - Times of India
text: BENGALURU: Several areas of the city remained under water for hours after heavy rain lashed the city on Thursday evening and early Friday morning, causing widespread damage and disrupting normal life. The heavy downpour also affected domestic flight services after water leakage in terminal-2 of the KIA. Several main roads were under water, prompting police to redirect traffic to alternative routes. Slow-moving traffic was reported due to waterlogging on Chowdiah Road towards High Grounds Junction and on Ballari Road towards Hebbal due to waterlogging at Sanjaynagar Cross. The situation was worse near RR Nagar Arch on Mysuru Road, where flooding halted incoming traffic towards Nayandahalli, requiring it to be diverted towards Jnanabharathi campus.The overnight flooding primarily affected Terminal 2 (T2) of the airport, which handles most domestic flights. Videos circulating on social media showed water entering the terminal building, causing inconvenience to passengers and impacting flight operations."A very heavy downpour of rain within a short span of time on the evening of May 9, 2024, resulted in water leakage in certain areas of the terminals at Bengaluru airport," Bangalore International Airport Limited (BIAL), which operates KIA, said in a statement.He said 13 domestic flights, three international passenger flights, and one international cargo flight were diverted to Chennai on Thursday."Our teams promptly responded to the situation to mitigate the impact and restore normal operations. We regret the inconvenience caused to our passengers". it added.The rain coupled with strong winds brought down many trees in several parts of the city including, Jayanagar, Nrupathunga Nagar and RR Nagar.The rains also brought relief to the Bengaluru residents from the blistering summer heat, which they had not witnessed for many decades.Ballari Road was flooded at Hunasamaranahalli near IAF station, leading to a jam of vehicles bound to and from KIA. Several Bengaluru-bound flights were also diverted due to the weather conditions.Over 70 trees were uprooted across the city. Those who had planned long-distance travel had a tough time reaching bus stands and railway stations.The city has been receiving rain for the past four days.According to the India Meteorological Department, Bengaluru city received 14 mm rain in the 24-hour period till 8.30 am on Friday.
